questions.text: 1. A biochemist is working on a study of enzyme activation in the fed and fasting state. He gives a dose of insulin to the study animal. Which of the following enzymes will be activated in response to this dose?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the high insulin/ well-fed/ dephosphorylated state.

The rest of the enzymes are active in the phosphorylated state/ low insulin/ fasting state.

Fasting state / low insulin state :

Liver: With a fall in the blood glucose levels, there is a fall in insulin levels with less uptake of glucose by muscle and adipose tissues. α-cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon, which inhibits glycogen synthetase and, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase (Option A). This eventually releases glucose into the bloodstream, intended for the use of the brain and RBCs.

Glucagon stimulates the production of cAMP, activating cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This, in turn, inactivates phosphofructokinase-2 and activates fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase (Option B) by phosphorylation.

Muscle: Acetyl-CoA, formed by oxidation of fatty acids, causes inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase, consequently leading to an accumulation of pyruvate. It is then converted to alanine, which is then transaminated back to pyruvate in the liver. This is used as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Adipose tissue: A fall in insulin and an increase in glucagon lead to inhibition of lipogenesis and activation of hormone-sensitive lipase (Option D). This leads to a massive release of glycerol, which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis in the liver. It is also utilised by the liver, heart, and skeletal muscle as metabolic fuel.

As fasting progresses, acetyl-CoA is used for the synthesis of ketone bodies, which are utilised by skeletal and heart muscles and up to 20% of the brain's energy source. After 18 hours of fasting, amino acids from protein catabolism are utilized by the liver and kidneys for gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: 2. Which of the following enzyme is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Phosphoglucomutase is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis.

The reaction catalyzed by phosphoglucomutase is reversible so that

* In glycogenesis: Glucose-6-phosphate is isomerized to glucose-1-phosphate

* In glycogenolysis: Glucose-6-phosphate can be formed from glucose-1-phosphate

Glycogen synthase is an enzyme of glycogenesis. Alpha-1,6-glucosidase and glycogen phosphorylase are enzymes of glycogenolysis.

questions.text: 3. A 4-month-old infant is found to have a profound neurologic deficit. On examination, the child is hypotonic, has a large anterior fontanelle, markedly separated cranial sutures, and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal elevated levels of very long-chain fatty acids. The dysfunction of which of the following cellular structures leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and investigations showing accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids are suggestive of Zellweger syndrome. The dysfunction of peroxisomes leads to this condition.

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

The child presents with: 

* Dysmorphic facial features like wide anterior fontanelles, markedly separated cranial sutures, epicanthal folds, etc

* Profound developmental delay

* Hepatomegaly

* Renal cysts

* Chondrodysplasia punctata - calcific stippling of the patellae, hips, and other epiphysis are seen in the majority of the patients.

Biochemical findings will show :

* Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, phytanic acid

* Abnormalities in the synthesis of bile acids

* Marked reduction of plasmalogens

There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Associated Disease

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: 4. The Myosin heavy chain (Mhc) gene in Drosophila encompasses a total of 30 exons which help transcribe many clusters of isoforms of length 2 to 5 exons. Supposing the canonical protein has a sequence of 262 amino acids and each isoform with 45-67 amino acids. What is the most probable phenomenon that can be noticed in this context?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed here is alternative splicing, as isoforms of proteins were transcribed from a single canonical protein. 

Alternative splicing is a form of gene regulation that can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogeneous nuclear RNA/primary transcript). Suppose there are exons 1, 2,3, and 4. The splicing can be 1-2, 1-3, 1-4, 2-4, 2-3, etc. This leads to the formation of many variants of a protein from a single hnRNA.

Alternative splicing has been identified in the case of at least 40 different genes. The calcitonin gene yields an RNA that synthesizes both calcitonin (in the thyroid) and calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP, in the brain). It is also responsible for the different types of tropomyosin variants in muscle.



Other options :

Option A: Transposons, also known as jumping genes, are DNA sequences that have the ability to autonomously relocate themselves throughout the genome. The DNA component of the transposon is transcribed into RNA, which is subsequently reverse-transcribed back into DNA. This DNA is then inserted into a different location within the genome. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

Option B: CpG methylation is an example of epigenetic modification, which leads to reduced or inhibited transcription. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

Option C: RNA interference is a process by which microRNAs target the untranslated region in the 3' end after transcription to enable degradation. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

questions.text: 5. Restriction fragment length polymorphisms may be produced by mutations in the sites for restriction endonucleases. For instance, a single base change in the site for the BamH I(restriction endonuclease) produces the sequence GGATGC, which can no longer be recognized by the enzyme. What is the original sequence that BamH I recognises?
questions.solution:
BamH I is a restriction endonuclease that recognises the sequence GGATCC, which is a palindromic sequence.

BamH I is unable to recognise the single base change GGATGC because it is not a palindromic sequence.

The complementary strand of GGATCC is CCTAGG. If we read this complementary strand in the 5’→3’ direction (its reverse complement), it becomes GGATCC, which is identical to the original sequence.

Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that cleave DNA at specific recognition sites. They typically recognize palindromic sequences, also known as inverted repeats. This means the nucleotide sequence on one strand from 5' to 3' is identical to the sequence on the complementary strand read in the same 5' to 3' direction.

The cuts made by these enzymes generally result in overlapping, or "sticky" ends, although some restriction endonucleases can also produce "blunt" ends. They are used to make restriction maps of DNA, produce fragments for genetic analysis, and make recombinant DNA and clone DNA sequences.

NOTE: It is interesting to note that BamH I is a restriction endonuclease derived from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens. 

Other options

Option A: The complementary strand of GGATGG is CCTACC, and if we read it in the 5’→3’ direction, the reverse complement is CCATCC. Comparing this with the original sequence, GGATGG is clearly not the same as its reverse complement, so it is not palindromic.

Option B: The complementary strand of GATAGC is CTATCG. Reading it 5’→3’ on the complementary strand gives the reverse complement GCTATC. This does not match the original sequence GATAGC, so it is not palindromic.

Option C: The complementary strand of CCATGC is GGTACG. Reading it 5’→3’ on the complementary strand gives the reverse complement GCATGG. This sequence is different from the original sequence CCATGC, so it is not palindromic.

questions.text: 6. A 10-year-old girl presented with the triad of diarrhoea, dermatitis, and delayed mental development. She has a positive Obermeyer test. Which of the following would be seen in the urine?
questions.solution:
Neutral aminoaciduria is seen in the urine in the given scenario.

The clinical features of pellagra, and a positive Obermeyer test point to the possibility of Hartnup’s disease, which exhibits neutral aminoaciduria; the presence of excessive neutral amino acids in the urine. Neutral amino acids have a net neutral charge at physiological pH: alanine, asparagine, glycine, serine, and threonine. 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to the mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on chromosome 5. As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced, and this manifests as pellagra, with dermatitis, diarrhoea, dementia, and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, thus distinguishing it from pellagra. Urine may also contain indican, which is produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Other options:

Option B: Branched-chain aminoaciduria is the presence of excessive branched-chain amino acids in the urine: leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Branched-chain aminoaciduria can be caused by: maple syrup urine disease, isovaleric acidemia, and methylmalonic acidemia.

Option C: Generalized aminoaciduria is the presence of excessive amounts of all amino acids in the urine. This can be caused by Fanconi syndrome, Lowe syndrome, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: Dibasic aminoaciduria is the presence of excessive amounts of basic amino acids in the urine. Basic amino acids are those that have a net positive charge at physiological pH: arginine, histidine, and lysine. Dibasic aminoaciduria can be caused by cystinuria and lysinuric protein intolerance.

questions.text: 7. A 2-month-old baby is brought to the clinic with a history of poor feeding, vomiting, and diarrhea. On examination, the child had icterus and an enlarged liver. Blood investigations revealed hypoglycemia, hypoalbuminemia, and elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood and urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of poor feeding, hepatomegaly, and hypoalbuminemia, with elevated levels of succinylacetone in the blood, is diagnostic of tyrosinemia type 1.

Tyrosinemia type Ⅰ It is due to the deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH). Accumulated metabolites in the blood, like fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, produce severe liver disease and defects in renal tubular function. The diagnosis is confirmed by an increased concentration of succinylacetone. Tyrosinemia type 1 is treated with nitisinone and a diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine.



Other options:

Option A: Tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) is due deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase, presents with ocular manifestations like excessive tearing, redness, pain, photophobia, and painful, nonpruritic hyperkeratotic plaques on the soles, palms, and fingertips. In contrast to type 1, liver and kidney functions and serum concentration of succinylacetone tend to be normal.

Option B: Tyrosinemia type III is due to a deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dehydrogenase mainly manifests as developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, and self-destructive behavior. In contrast to type 1 shows increased plasma levels of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites, urinary 4-hydroxyphenyllactate and 4-hydroxyphenylacetate.

Option C: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to the deficiency of fructose-1-phosphate aldolase(aldolase-B). It has a similar clinical scenario, but the accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate also results in inhibition of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, resulting in decreased glucose production.

questions.text:
8. A 3-year-old child has been referred by a PHC to a tertiary care hospital for evaluation of his developmental delay. On further examination, it was found that the child is found to be tall for his age with elongated limbs, and the eye showed an inferonasal subluxation of the lens with severe myopia. The deficiency of which of the following vitamins will cause the given clinical condition in this child?

* Vitamin B2

* Vitamin B5

* Vitamin B6

* Vitamin B9

* Vitamin B12
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin B6, vitamin B9, and vitamin B12 will cause the given clinical condition in this child.

In the given clinical scenario, the child is found to be tall for his age, with elongated limbs and eyes showing inferonasal subluxation of the lens. He is likely suffering from homocystinuria, which can be due to a deficiency of either vitamin B6, vitamin B9, or vitamin B12.

Homocystinuria is an inborn error of methionine metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase. It is characterized by tall stature, long limbs mimicking Marfan's disease (Marfanoid habitus), inferonasal subluxation of the lens, thromboembolism, intellectual disability, psychiatric and behavioral disorders.



Cystathionine β-synthase is dependent on cofactor vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine), which converts homocysteine to cystathionine. Hence deficiency of Vitamin B6 will lead to the accumulation of homocysteine in blood and urine, causing homocystinuria.

5-methyl-tetrahydrofolate(TFH) and homocysteine together react in the presence of methionine synthase to give methionine and tetrahydrofolate.

Methionine synthase uses vitamin B12 as a cofactor; hence, deficiency of vitamin B12 will also lead to accumulation of Homocysteine in blood and urine, causing homocystinuria.

Similarly, a deficiency of vitamin B9 (Tetrahydrofolate) will lead to the accumulation of homocysteine in blood and urine, causing homocystinuria. Hence, homocystinuria can be caused by the deficiency of either vitamin B6, vitamin B9, or vitamin B12.



Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens.

Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Pearl PM2304: Homocystinuria



The concept for treatment:

* Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.

* As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: 9. The image shows a graph plotted between rate of reaction (on y axis) and substrate concentration (on x axis). Which of the statements is not true regarding this plot?

choices.text: It is a property of monomeric enzymes
The enzyme may have multiple binding sites

questions.solution:
The graph shown in the image is not a property of monomeric enzymes.

The graph shown in the image is a sigmoid-shaped graph, which is a property of multimeric enzymes.

Multimeric enzymes have multiple subunits (Option D). When the enzyme has many subunits, binding of substrate to one unit enhances the affinity for binding to other subunits. This is called cooperative binding (Option B).

In such cases, a sigmoid-shaped saturation curve is obtained. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes. They do not follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics (Option A). The Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding.

Allosteric enzymes are those for which catalysis at the active site may be modulated by the presence of effectors at an allosteric site. This is the exclusive property of multimeric enzymes, which have multiple binding sites for enzymes. This property is analogous to oxygen binding by hemoglobin. This is not seen in monomeric enzymes.

As the Michaelis-Menten equations cannot be used, the Hill equation is used to describe the kinetics of positive cooperative binding. Allosteric enzymes have one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds.

questions.text: 10. A 33-year-old fitness enthusiast comes to the clinic with itching of the skin and lethargy. He also has muscle pains and anorexia. On examination, he has dermatitis around the eyes, nose and mouth. Further evaluation reveals a deficiency of the vitamin which functions as a cofactor in the reaction below. This vitamin is not required for which of these other reactions?
questions.solution:
Conversion of malate to oxaloacetate does not require the vitamin deficient in the given scenario.

The given clinical complex describes the symptom complex of a patient with biotin deficiency. Conversion of malate to oxaloacetate is catalysed by the enzyme malate dehydrogenase. This reaction does not require biotin as a cofactor.

Biotin serves as an important cofactor in carboxylation reactions, where biotin functions as a carrier for the activated carbon dioxide molecule.

Biotin deficiency is commonly seen in patients who consume large quantities of egg whites (as is possible in this patient who is a fitness enthusiast), containing avidin that binds to biotin and prevents absorption. Clinical features of biotin deficiency are dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations.

Biotin-dependent carboxylation:

* Acetyl CoA carboxylase

* Pyruvate carboxylase

* Propionyl CoA carboxylase

* Methyl crotonyl CoA carboxylase

Biotin-independent carboxylation:

* Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase

* Addition of CO2 to form C6 in the purine ring

* Malic enzyme

questions.text: 11. A 9-month-old infant with developmental delay underwent an extensive biochemical workup, and investigations revealed the accumulation of a class of chemical compounds, the structure of which is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of this class compound is seen in Tay-Sachs disease.

The class compound given in the image is a glucosphingolipid. Glucosphingolipids are made up of three components

* Sphingosine unit

* Fatty acid unit

* Sugar unit

The deficiency of the enzyme beta-hexosaminidase A causes Tay-Sachs. In GM2 gangliosidosis, glucosphingolipid accumulates, presenting with clinical features that include loss of motor skills, an increased startle reflex, retinal cherry-red spots, and macrocephaly without hydrocephaly



Other options:

Option A: Pompe's disease is a type of glycogen storage disorder caused by a deficiency of acid alpha-glycosidase (acid maltase), leading to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes.

Option C: Wolman's disease is a result of lysosomal acid lipase deficiency leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides in histiocytic foam cells of most visceral organs.

Option D: Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis II (MPS II), resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

questions.text:
12. Discoidal HDL is converted to HDL3 by the action of :

LCAT: Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl Transferase
questions.solution:
Discoidal HDL is converted to HDL3 by the action of LCAT (Lecithin Cholesterol Acyl Transferase).

LCAT converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL, thus converting discoidal HDL to HDL3 and then to HDL2. This is an important part of reverse cholesterol transport to the liver.





Other options : 

Option A: Cholesterol ester transfer protein(CTEP)- When HDL 3 is in circulation, the cholesterol ester from HDL is transferred to VLDL, IDL, and LDL by cholesterol ester transfer protein. This will help product inhibition of LCAT so that more cholesterol can be taken up.

Option C: Apo-A1- It is an apoprotein present on HDL, which activates LCAT and aids in the uptake of mature HDL spheres by the liver through the apo-A-1-mediated receptor mechanism. 

Option D: Lipoprotein lipase- It is located at the endothelial layer of capillaries of adipose tissue, muscle, and heart.Apo-C-Ⅱ present on chylomicrons activates the LpL, which hydrolyzes triglycerides present in chylomicrons into fatty acids and glycerol.

questions.text: 13. Tri-peptide X, which is an important antioxidant, takes part in the Meister cycle. Which of the following three amino acids make up this tripeptide X?
questions.solution:
The tripeptide-X is glutathione, which is formed by glycine, cysteine, and glutamate, and plays a central role in the Meister cycle.

The Meister Cycle, also known as the γ-glutamyl cycle, is a pathway that facilitates the absorption of neutral amino acids in the intestines, kidney tubules, and brain. In this cycle, the central role is played by glutathione, which acts as a carrier molecule. This cycle is not the pathway responsible for the synthesis of glutathione.

Glutathione reacts with the incoming amino acid to form a γ-glutamyl-amino acid conjugate, a reaction catalyzed by γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT). This γ-glutamyl–amino acid is then transported into the cell and further cleaved to release the free amino acid, resulting in the net transfer of one amino acid across the membrane.

Functions of glutathione:

* Absorption of neutral amino acids by the Meister cycle

* Coenzyme role for the reduction reaction

* RBC membrane integrity

* Maintain the hemoglobin in the reduced (ferrous) state, which prevents methemoglobinemia

* Conjugation and detoxification

Glutathione, found in red blood cells (RBCs), plays a crucial role in neutralizing free radicals. This process relies on glutathione peroxidase, a selenium-containing enzyme. Reduced glutathione is then regenerated by glutathione reductase, an enzyme dependent on NADPH.

NADPH is supplied by the glucose-6-phosphate (GPD) shunt pathway. Therefore, a deficiency in GPD can lead to hemolysis due to impaired regeneration of reduced glutathione.

questions.text: 14. Which of the following enzymes is not present in the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
The enzyme thiokinase is not present in the fatty acid synthase complex. 

The six enzymes in FAS are:

* Ketoacyl synthase (Option D)

* Malonyl/acetyl transacylase

* Dehydratase

* Enoyl reductase (Option A)

* Ketoacyl reductase

* ACP(acyl carrier protein)

* Thioesterase  (Option B)

Fatty acid synthesis occurs in the cytosol. It involves the formation of palmitate from acetyl-CoA. This process occurs in the liver, kidney, brain, lung, breast, and adipose tissue. Acetyl-CoA and CO2 act as the substrates, and palmitate is the end product.

Acetyl-CoA is carboxylated to form malonyl-CoA by ATP and acetyl-CoA carboxylase as the initial step. This enzyme requires biotin and is the regulatory enzyme in fatty acid synthesis. 

Malonyl-CoA is acted upon by the fatty acid synthase complex(FAS). FAS consists of six enzymes with an acyl carrier protein arranged in a homodimer in an "X-shape". Acyl carrier protein(ACP) contains pantothenic acid.

Thioesterase is the last enzyme in the fatty acid synthase complex. It catalyzes the final release of the newly formed fatty acid. 

Note: Thiokinase catalyzes the only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA. Acyl-CoA is the active form of fatty acid. This step uses one high-energy phosphate and forms AMP and PPi.

Pearl PM0480: Fatty Acid Synthesis Pathway

Steps

Reactions

Activation

Acetyl-CoA carboxylation

Elongation

The malonyl-CoA pathway

Condensation step 

Covalent linking of acetyl-CoA and Malonyl-CoA (with the release of CoA and carbon dioxide)

Reduction step 

Acetoacetyl-ACP to ß-hydroxybutryl-ACP (using up one NADPH2)

Dehydration step 

ß-hydroxybutryl-ACP to crotonyl-ACP (with the release of a water molecule)

Another reduction step

Crotonyl-ACP to butryl-ACP (using up a second NADPH2)

questions.text:
15. Match the following urine tests with respective substances they detect.

Test

 Substance

1. Rothera test

 A. Urobilinogen

2. Benedict's test

 B. Bile salts

3. Hay's test

 C. Glucose

4. Ehrlich's test

 D. Acetoacetate
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

Rothera’s test by nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether acetone or acetoacetate is present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test. Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate.  

The other test used for the purpose of detecting acetoacetate only is the ferric chloride test. It shows a burgundy red color that is graded from +1 to +4. False-positive results occur with drugs like salicylates and phenols. 

The image below shows the purple ring formed by a positive Rothera test.



Benedict's test is a test commonly used in the follow-up of diabetics for the detection of glucose in urine (glucosuria). It uses Benedict's reagent containing sodium carbonate, copper sulfate, and sodium citrate. Reducing sugars (containing a free aldehyde/ keto group) will reduce Benedict's reagent. Examples include glucose, fructose, and lactose.

The test is a semi-quantitative test. The blue color indicates no reducing sugar. 

Color Concentration
Green 0.5 g%
Yellow 1 g%
Orange 1.5 g%
Red 2 g%




Hay's test is used for the detection of bile salts in urine. Normally, bile salts (sodium salts of taurocholic acid and glycocholic acid) are not present in urine. Thus, positive Hay's test indicates an obstructive pathology in the biliary system, leading to the backflow of bile into the circulation. This obstruction may be associated with either obstructive jaundice or hepatic jaundice.

Ehrlich's test is used to determine urinary and fecal urobilinogen. 

Porphobilinogens form a red aldehyde compound with Ehrlich reagent, which is insoluble in chloroform. A red color remaining after chloroform extraction is indicative of porphobilinogens. This test is positive in acute intermittent porphyria and hemolytic jaundice. It is negative in hepatic jaundice (later stages) and obstructive jaundice. The earliest sign of recovery in obstructive jaundice is the re-appearance of urobilinogen in urine.

questions.text: 16. A mutation occurs in the codon for glycine, changing it from GGU to GGC. However, the resulting protein shows no change in amino acid sequence. What type of mutation is this?
questions.solution:
A mutation that does not change the amino acid sequence is called a silent mutation.

Silent point mutation: a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. There will be no detectable effect due to the degeneracy of the code.

The base U is replaced by C due to a point mutation that changes the codon from GGU to GGC, both of which code for glycine. Hence, there is no change in the amino acid sequence.

Other options:

Option A: Non-sense point mutation: the point mutation may change the amino acid codon to a chain terminator. Example: β-globulin CAG (glutamine), U is substituted for C, leading to the production of UAG, a stop codon.caused β°thalassemia  

Option C: Missense point mutation: the mutation that alters the amino acid in the protein. These are of 2 types:

* Non-conservative (non-homogeneous)- a replaced amino acid will lead to a biochemically different protein. Example- Hemoglobin S 

* Conservative (homogeneous)- replaced amino acid leads to little change in the function of the protein. Example- Hemoglobin C

Option D: Transversion mutations are changes in the DNA in which a purine is changed to either of the two pyrimidines or a pyrimidine is changed to either of the two purines.

questions.text: 17. In which one of the following tissues is glucose transport into the cell insulin-dependent?
questions.solution:
Glucose transport into the cell is insulin-dependent in the adipose tissue.

The glucose transporter GLUT-4 in adipose tissue, cardiac, and skeletal muscles is insulin-dependent. Insulin results in the transport of GLUT-4 from intracellular vesicles to the cell membrane. The brain, liver, and red blood cells contain GLUTs that are independent of insulin because they are always located on the cell membrane.

Glucose transporters may be facilitative bidirectional transporters, such as GLUT, or sodium-dependent unidirectional transporters, such as SGLT.

  Tissue Location Functions
GLUT 1 Brain, kidney, colon, placenta, erythrocytes Glucose uptake
GLUT 2 Liver, pancreatic β cells, small intestine, and kidney Rapid uptake or release of glucose
GLUT 3 Brain, kidney, placenta Glucose uptake
GLUT 4 Heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake
GLUT 5 Small intestine Absorption of fructose
SGLT 1 Small intestine and kidney Active uptake of glucose against a concentration gradient

questions.text: 18. In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme. After 10 minutes of reaction, 1% of the substrate is converted to product (10 μg/mL). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and the concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into 20 μg/mL of the product?
questions.solution:
The time taken for the formation of 20 μg/mL of the product is 60 minutes.

When the substrate concentration is much greater than the Km value, the rate of the reaction is independent of the substrate concentration i.e. it follows zero-order kinetics. In this reaction, the substrate concentration is 1000 times the Km value therefore it follows zero-order kinetics. So, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction.

The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. As the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd, the velocity of the reaction also becomes 1/3.

Hence the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled. That is 10 × 3 = 30 minutes. Therefore time taken to form twice the product which is 20 micrograms/ml is doubled i.e 60 minutes.

Alternatively, for zero-order kinetics, 10 μg/mL in 10 minutes gives a reaction rate of 1 μg/m/min. To make a product of 20 μg/mL it would take 20 minutes. since the enzymes are cut to 1/3 rd of their initial concentration, it will take 3 times the original time for the same product i.e 20*3= 60 minutes.

questions.text: 19. A software employee came for a master health checkup. Blood samples for glucose level estimation were taken in a test tube containing a particular substance that inhibits enzyme enolase during glycolysis. What is that substance?
questions.solution:
The substance in the blood sample test tube that inhibits the enzyme enolase during glycolysis is fluoride.

Enolase plays an important role in glycolysis by catalyzing 2- 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, and it requires magnesium ions to do this process. Fluoride irreversibly inhibits the enzyme by removing the magnesium ions.

If fluoride is not added, the glucose would be metabolized, causing a lower sugar value to be obtained. Therefore, blood samples are taken in tubes containing fluoride to inhibit glycolysis.



Other options:

Option A: Iodoacetate inhibits the enzyme glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase, which converts glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate during glycolysis. 

Option B and D: Fluoracetate, arsenite, and malonate are inhibitors in the Kreb's cycle.

Enzyme Inhibitor
Aconitase Fluoroacetate
Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Arsenite
Succinate dehydrogenase Malonate

questions.text: 20. Which of the following is a non-essential amino-acid that is both glucogenic and ketogenic?
questions.solution:
Tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid that is both ketogenic and glucogenic. 

Phenylalanine, tryptophan, and isoleucine are both ketogenic and glucogenic but are considered nutritionally essential amino acids.

Tyrosine undergoes catabolism that produces: 1. Fumarate: An intermediate of the TCA cycle. Can enter gluconeogenesis → glucogenic pathway. 2. Acetoacetate (a ketone body precursor): Can be converted to acetyl-CoA or ketone bodies.



Ketogenic amino acids: Their carbon skeletons are degraded to acetoacetate, acetyl-CoA, or acetoacetyl-CoA. These are precursors for ketone bodies or fatty acids, not glucose. E.g., Leucine and lysine.

Both glucogenic and ketogenic: Some amino acids give rise to both TCA intermediates (then to glucose) and acetyl-CoA/ketone bodies. E.g., Isoleucine, phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan.

Glucogenic amino acids: Their carbon skeletons are degraded to pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediates (like oxaloacetate, α-ketoglutarate, succinyl-CoA, fumarate). These intermediates can be converted into glucose via gluconeogenesis. All other 14 amino acids are glucogenic.

Essential Amino Acids: They cannot be synthesized de novo in sufficient quantities by humans. They must be obtained from the diet. E.g., Isoleucine, Leucine, Threonine, Lysine, Methionine, Phenylalanine, Tryptophan, and Valine.

Non-Essential Amino Acids: Can be synthesized in the body, usually from intermediates of glycolysis, TCA cycle, or essential AAs.

questions.text: 21. Which of the following statements about ATP synthase is false

choices.text: It is located in the inner mitochondrial membrane
It requires a proton motive force to form ATP in the presence of ADP and Pi
ATP is produced when part of the molecule rotates
One ATP molecule is formed for each full revolution of the molecule

questions.solution:
Option D is false, as one ATP is not generated for each full revolution of the molecule.

Three ATP molecules are generated for each full revolution of the molecule, not one ATP.

ATP synthase is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane (Option A), together with the respiratory chain complexes. The proton motive force (Option B) drives a membrane-located ATP synthase that forms ATP in the presence of Pi + ADP. ATP is produced when part of the molecule rotates. Several subunits of the protein form a ball-like shape arranged around an axis known as F1.

F1 is attached to a membrane protein complex known as F໐. F໐ spans the membrane and forms a proton channel. As a proton flows through F໐ driven by the proton gradient across the membrane, it rotates, driving the production of ATP (Option C).

During the production of ATP in the F1 complex, this occurs by a binding change mechanism in which the conformation of the β subunit in F1 is changed as the axis rotates from one that binds ATP tightly to one that releases ATP and binds to ADP and Pi, so the next ATP is formed 

Note that there are 3 α and 3 β subunits. The β subunits take up ADP and Pi to form ATP. Since there are 3 β subunits, 3ATP molecules are formed for each revolution.

questions.text: 22. A child presents with clinical features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. A genetic investigation which detects exon deletions is ordered. The image of the investigation is shown below. Identify the investigation?
questions.solution:
The investigation shown is multiple ligation probe amplification (MPLA).

Multiple ligation probe amplification can be used for the detection of exon deletion/ duplication (exon level copy number variation) in the dystrophin gene. In MPLA, DNA is first denatured to single stranded state and hybridized with specific probes that contain PCR primer binding sites. Then these hybridized strands are amplified and separated by capillary gel electrophoresis and presence or absence of different amplicons is analysed to identify missing exons.

Other option:

Option B: Southern blotting- It is based on specific base pairing properties of complementary nucleic acid strands. This technique is therefore based on DNA hybridization, which is used to detect a specific segment of DNA.



Option C: Microarray technique- DNA probes of about 500-5000 genes are prepared and added to very small wells in polyester plates. cDNA prepared from the patient's tissue is added to each well, and fluorescence is addressed. So the presence and expression of various genes are identified quickly.



Option D: Sanger's sequencing- It is based on constructing a complementary DNA (cDNA) copy of the molecule using deoxy nucleoside triphosphate (dNTPs), a specific synthetic oligonucleotide primer, and a DNA polymerase.

questions.text: 23. A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive night blindness and constricted visual fields. Fundus examination reveals chorioretinal atrophy and plasma studies show markedly elevated ornithine levels.Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is responsible?
questions.solution:
Ornithine aminotransferase deficiency is responsible for the clinical presentation.

Night blindness, constricted visual field, chorioretinal atrophy with raised plasma ornithine levels point toward the diagnosis of gyrate atrophy, which occurs due to deficiency of ornithine aminotransferase (OAT)

Gyrate atrophy is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder, is caused by biallelic pathogenic variants in OAT, leading to deficient ornithine aminotransferase activity. 

Clinically, some patients may experience hyperammonemia in the first months of life. Ocular changes typically begin between 5-10 years of age, progressing to complete blindness by the fourth decade. These changes include night blindness, myopia, loss of peripheral vision, posterior subcapsular cataracts, and atrophic retinal lesions resembling cerebral gyri. Neurologically, patients typically exhibit normal intelligence.

Biochemically, plasma ornithine levels are characteristically increased 10 to 20-fold (400-1,400 μmol/L), while glutamate, glutamine, lysine, creatine, and creatinine can be moderately decreased.

Management of gyrate atrophy:

* Restrict ornithine

* Restrict arginine (source of ornithine)

* Vitamin B6 supplementation

Transamination is the transfer of the amino group (NH2) from an amino acid to a keto acid. It is a pyridoxal phosphate (PLP, an active form of Vitamin B6) dependent reaction. All amino acids undergo transamination except:

* Lysine

* Threonine

* Proline

* Hydroxyproline

Other options :

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamoylase- It is an enzyme of the urea cycle. Deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type 2, the most common of all the urea cycle disorders. It usually manifests as vomiting and neurological abnormalities(ataxia, mental confusion, agitation), increased urine orotic acid excretion, and raised plasma glutamine levels.

Option C: Ornithine decarboxylase- It catalyses the reaction of conversion of Ornithine to putrescine, not linked to gyrate atrophy.

Option D: Ornithine cyclodeaminase- It catalyzes the conversion of L-ornithine to L-proline; this pathway only functions in a few bacteria.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 24. A young chemist notices a reaction system in which the rate of conversion of substrates to product is equal to the rate at which products are converted back to substrates. Which of the following properties regarding this reaction system is true?

choices.text: The equilibrium constant is a ratio of the reaction rates
The rate constants  of the forward and backward reactions are equal
The value of equilibrium constant increases with increase in catalyst or enzyme concentration

questions.solution:
Among the given options, equilibrium is a dynamic state is the correct option.

In an equilibrium state, although there is no net change in the concentration of substrates or products, individual substrate and product molecules are continually being interconverted, and hence it is said to be dynamic.

Key properties of a system at equilibrium include:

* Equilibrium constant (Keq): This is a ratio of the reaction rate constants, not the reaction rates themselves (Option A).

* Reaction rates: At equilibrium, the rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal. However, the rate constants are not necessarily equal (Option B).

* Calculation of Keq: The numerical value of Keq can be determined either from the concentrations of substrates and products at equilibrium or from the ratio of the reaction rate constants.

* Dynamic state: Equilibrium is not static. While there's no net change in the concentrations of substrates or products, individual molecules are constantly interconverting. This dynamic nature can be demonstrated by adding a trace of a radioisotopic product to an equilibrium system, which will then show the appearance of radiolabelled substrate.

* If Keq is more than 1, the forward reaction is favoured. In such instances, the reaction is spontaneous and exothermic.

* The concentration of the enzyme does not affect the Keq (Option D). The concentration of the enzyme certainly increases the rate of reaction, but not the Keq or the ultimate state. Catalysts increase the rate of reaction but do not alter the equilibrium.

questions.text: 26. A biochemist performs the cyanide nitroprusside test on a non-essential, purely glucogenic amino acid. The test is positive for the same. Identify the amino acid being tested.
questions.solution:
Cysteine is a non-essential, glucogenic amino acid that tests positive for the cyanide nitroprusside test.

Cyanide nitroprusside test: It is a screening test for cystinuria.

Cyanide nitroprusside breaks the S-S bond (disulfide bond) and releases free sulfhydryl groups, which react with sodium nitroprusside to give a reddish color. The test is positive for cysteine.

The sulfur test can also be performed to detect free sulfhydryl groups.

Other options:

Option A: Glycine is a non-essential, purely glucogenic amino acid and tests negative for nitroprusside reaction. It does not contain the sulfhydryl group. 

Option C: Threonine is an essential, purely glucogenic amino acid. It contains a hydroxyl group and hence tests negative for the nitroprusside reaction

Option D: Tyrosine is a non-essential glucogenic and ketogenic amino acid. It contains a phenol group and hence tests negative for the nitroprusside reaction.

questions.text: 27. A 7-year-old boy was diagnosed with hypophosphatemic rickets. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the dentin matrix protein 1 gene. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Autosomal recessive(B) is the type of inheritance of this type of hypophosphatemic rickets.

Autosomal recessive  hypophosphatemic rickets has three types

* Type 1-caused by a pathological variant of DMP-1

* Type 2-caused by a pathological variant of ENPP-1

* Type 3-caused by a pathological variant of FAM20C

They are associated with elevated levels of FGF 23. Excess FGF23 decreases phosphate reabsorption by the proximal tubule and inhibits renal 1-𝛼-hydroxylase, leading to decreased production of 1,25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol.

Evaluation of hypophosphatemic rickets:



Other options:

Option A- Autosomal dominant -Patients with autosomal dominant hypophosphatemic rickets have a pathological variant in the gene encoding for FGF23, which prevents its degradation by proteases, leading to excess FGF23 activity.

Option C- X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets has a pathological variant of the PHEX gene. The product of this gene inactivates FGF23. A defect in the PHEX gene leads to an elevated level of FGF23.

Option D- There is no inheritance of hypophosphatemic rickets by the X-linked recessive mode of inheritance.

Pearl PM2198: Vitamin D activation and Rickets



Pearl PM1959: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

* Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 

* Delayed appearance of the epiphysis

* Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.

* Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.

* Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

* Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices

* In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

* Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia

* Wrist: especially the ulna

* Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary



The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: 28. Arsenite inhibits which of the following steps of the TCA cycle

choices.text: Conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Arsenite inhibits the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA by non-competitively inhibiting α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.

Arsenite is an inorganic salt form of the metal Arsenic and is highly toxic. It is present in pesticides, rodenticides, wood preservatives, etc.

* Fluroacetate inhibits the enzyme aconitase in a non-competitive manner, which affects the conversion of citrate to isocitrate (Option A). Fluroacetate is found in some plants, and anticancer drugs are metabolized to fluroacetyl-CoA, which condenses with oxaloacetate to form flurocitrate, with aconitase causing citrate to accumulate

* Malonate competitively inhibits the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase. which affects the conversion of succinate to fumarate(Option D)

questions.text: 29. A 9-year-old boy was brought in with complaints of a fishy smell in his hands, feet, saliva, and urine. A urinalysis revealed the substance responsible for the odor, and a diagnosis of fish odor syndrome was made. Which vitamin can be administered to help alleviate his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Administration of vitamin B2 will help alleviate the symptoms.

In the presented clinical picture of trimethylaminuria, the distinct odour is attributed to the presence of trimethylamine (TMA), which is excreted through perspiration, urine, and exhaled breath.

The administration of vitamin B2/ riboflavin can potentially improve the symptoms experienced by this patient. This is because riboflavin serves as a cofactor for the enzyme flavin-containing monooxygenase 3, which catalyzes the breakdown of trimethylamine.

Fish odour syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is an autosomal recessive disease. It is due to a deficiency of flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 (FMO3), which converts the amino acid, TMA (trimethylamine), to TMA-N-oxide (which is non-odorous) in the liver. TMA thus builds up in the body and is released in sweat, urine, and breath, giving off a strong odor of rotting fish from the body.

Patients present in childhood or early adulthood with halitosis or body odor (distinctive fishy odor). Patients suffer from psychosocial problems such as shame, anxiety, depression, etc. Diagnosis is based on high levels of excreted trimethylamine (TMA) in the patient's urine. 

Treatment involves avoiding foods containing choline, such as egg, liver, peas, and soy products. A short course of antibiotics such as neomycin and metronidazole can be given, which reduces the production of trimethylamine by the gut bacteria, or even the administration of vitamin B2/ riboflavin.

questions.text: 30. A 5-year-old child presents with corneal clouding with normal intelligence and no features of visceromegaly. Lysosomal storage disorder is suspected. Enzyme assay shows N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulphatase deficiency. Which of the following is the most appropriate enzyme replacement therapy?
questions.solution:
Elosulphase is the enzyme replacement therapy for this condition.

Corneal clouding, normal intelligence, with a deficiency of N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulphatase point towards the diagnosis of Morquio A syndrome. Elosulphase (Vimizim) is used for enzyme replacement therapy for Morquio syndrome.

questions.text: 31. A 2-day-old neonate presents with persistent bleeding from the umbilical cord stump for more than 24 hours. The baby was delivered at home. Which of the following biochemical reactions is most likely to be affected in this neonate?
questions.solution:
Post-translational carboxylation of glutamate is affected in the given scenario.

The clinical picture of persistent bleeding from the umbilical cord stump is classically seen in hemorrhagic disease of the newborn that occurs because of vitamin K deficiency.

Vitamin K is required as a cofactor in the post-translational carboxylation of glutamate residues of factors II, VII, IX, and X. Calcium binds to γ-­carboxylated glutamic acid residues that are present in these factors during clotting.

Vitamin K deficiency is common in neonates, as breast milk is a poor source of vitamin K and the sterile gastrointestinal tract of the newborn lacks the required bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

All newborn infants are to be administered vitamin K at a dose of 0.5–1 mg intramuscularly to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.



Other options:

Option A: Cross-linking of collagen and elastin requires copper as a cofactor. Deficiency in this process can lead to connective tissue disorders like Menkes syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome.

Option B: Hydroxylation of proline occurs during collagen synthesis and requires vitamin C as a cofactor. Deficiency can present as scurvy, in which easy bruising can occur, but it is not common in the neonatal period.

Option C: Synthesis of thymidylate occurs during DNA synthesis and requires folate as a cofactor. Deficiency of folate may present as megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: 32. In the fasting state, which of the following cycles provides a major source of glucose for the body from skeletal muscle breakdown?
questions.solution:
In a fasting state, the Cahill cycle, also known as the glucose-alanine cycle, provides the major source of glucose for the body from muscle breakdown.

In a fasting state, muscles release a significant amount of alanine, exceeding the quantity produced by the catabolism of muscle proteins. This alanine is formed through the transamination of pyruvate, which itself is a product of muscle glycogen glycolysis.

Alanine is then transported to the liver, where it undergoes transamination back to pyruvate and serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis. This process, known as the glucose-alanine cycle or the Cahill cycle, indirectly utilizes muscle glycogen to help maintain blood glucose levels during fasting.

Other options :

Option A: The process of reconversion of lactate formed in the muscles back to glucose inside the liver is called Cori's cycle / glucose-lactate cycle. Lactic acid is a metabolic byproduct formed after anaerobic glycolysis in tissues such as the skeletal muscles and erythrocytes. The lactate so formed is transported into the liver and kidney. Here, it gets reconverted back into pyruvate which can be converted to glucose. 

Option C: Krebs cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins because glucose, fatty acids, and most amino acids are metabolized to acetyl-CoA or intermediates of the cycle.

Option D: Rapoport - luebering cycle takes place in the red blood cells (RBC). Here 1, 3- Bisphosphoglycerate kinase is bypassed, no ATPs are produced in that step. Only 2 ATPs are generated by the pyruvate kinase step and 2 ATPs are utilized in the steps catalyzed by hexokinase and Phosphofructokinase - 1.So this pathway yields no net generation of ATP from glycolysis.

Pearl PM2309: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text: 34. Blue diaper syndrome is due to malabsorption of ___________
questions.solution:
Blue diaper syndrome is due to malabsorption of tryptophan.

Blue diaper syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by tryptophan malabsorption due to a defect in the basolateral tryptophan transporter (SCL16A10). It is also known as Drummond syndrome.

The unabsorbed tryptophan is converted to indican by intestinal bacteria and excreted in the urine. The excreted indicans are oxidized to indigo blue, which is responsible for the bluish discoloration of diapers seen in this syndrome.

Other features include

* Nephrocalcinosis

* Ocular abnormalities

* Hypercalcemia

* Vomiting

* Constipation

* Loss of appetite

* Failure to thrive

questions.text: 36. In noncompetitive inhibition of the enzyme, it is observed that

choices.text: Vmax of the reaction remains same

questions.solution:
Noncompetitive inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

Graph showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition.

questions.text: 37. A 9-month-old infant has failure to thrive and developmental delay. Laboratory evaluation reveals megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to folate and vitamin B12 supplementation. Urinary orotic acid levels are markedly elevated. Which of the following enzyme defects best explains this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The UMP synthase enzyme defect explains the patient's condition.

Megaloblastic anemia unresponsive to Vit B12 and folate supplementation, with markedly elevated orotic acid, points towards the diagnosis of hereditary orotic aciduria.

This condition results from a deficiency of orotate phosphoribosyltransferase(OPRTase) and orotidine-5-monophosphate(OMP) decarboxylase. These enzymes are together known as UMP synthase.

Individuals affected by this condition are unable to convert orotic acid into UMP, leading to the excretion of large amounts of orotic acid in their urine. These levels can be so high that orotic acid crystals may form and precipitate within the renal collecting system. This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Most affected individuals typically present within the first few weeks or months of life with failure to thrive and developmental delay. The majority experience megaloblastic anemia, along with hypochromia, anisocytosis, and poikilocytosis.

In some cases, strabismus, congenital malformations, or seizures have also been observed. Notably, heterozygous carriers may excrete high levels of orotic acid without exhibiting any additional symptoms.

Differential diagnosis of elevated urine orotic acid levels :

* Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency 

* Reyes syndrome

* Medications like allopurinol and azauridine.

Definitive diagnosis of hereditary orotic aciduria comes from genetic testing that reveals pathogenic variants in the UMPS gene and enzyme measured in blood cells and fibroblasts. Uridine triacetate is used for treating this condition.



Other options : 

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency causes hyperammonemia type 2, which presents with features of hyperammonemia (vomiting and neurological manifestations) with elevated plasma glutamine and alanine and reduced plasma citrulline and arginine, and elevated urinary orotic acid excretion. In contrast to hereditary orotic aciduria does not present with megaloblastic anemia.

Option B: Carbamoyl phosphate synthase 1 deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type 1, presents with features of hyperammonemia but no megaloblastic anemia, and urinary orotic acid is usually low or absent

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), with a defect of both humoral and cellular immunity.

questions.text: 38. Urea and Kreb's cycle are linked by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Urea and the Krebs cycle are linked by fumarate.

The ammonia from all over the body reaches the liver and is detoxified to urea (the major end product of protein catabolism) by liver cells and excreted by the kidneys. It partly takes place in mitochondria and partly in the cytoplasm.

The products of the urea cycle obtained by cleavage of argininosuccinate are arginine and fumarate by the enzyme arginosuccinate lyase. This fumarate enters the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle) to be finally converted to oxaloacetate, hence also referred to as the urea bicycle.

questions.text: 39. A 28-year-old man presents with dementia, dermatitis, and diarrhea. Has been on long-term isoniazid therapy for the management of pulmonary tuberculosis. Urine analysis shows increased excretion of xanthurenic acid. Defect in the activity of which of the following enzymes best explains the clinical features?
questions.solution:
Defect in the activity of kynureninase best explains the clinical features.

A 28-year-old man with dementia, dermatitis, and diarrhea points towards a diagnosis of pellagra, and long-term isoniazid therapy with increased excretion of xanthurenic acid points towards pyridoxine deficiency (Vitamin B6).

Kynureninase, which catalyses the conversion of 3-hydroxykynurenine to 3-hydroxyanthranilate, uses pyridoxine as a cofactor. Due to a deficiency of pyridoxine kynureninase reaction is blocked, and 3-hydroxykynurenine is diverted to form xanthurenate, which is excreted in urine and reduces the synthesis of NAD and NADP from tryptophan; hence, symptoms of pellagra are observed in pyridoxine deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Tryptophan hydroxylase catalyses the conversion of tryptophan to 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is further converted to serotonin by a decarboxylase enzyme. Tryptophan hydroxylase does not use pyridoxine as a cofactor.

Option B: Kynurenine hydroxylase catalyses the conversion of kynurenine to 3-hydroxykynurenine.

Option D: Tryptophan pyrrolase or oxygenase catalyses the conversion of tryptophan to formylkynurenine.

Pearl PM2196: Amino Acid Derivatives



Pearl PM0575: Xanthurenic aciduria

questions.text: 40. A 25-year-old man who came for a routine health examination is noted to have reducing sugar in urine, giving Benedict's test positive. However, his glucose tolerance test is normal; further investigation shows a positive Bial's test. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and which sugar is excreted in urine?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is essential pentosuria, and the sugar excreted in urine is L-xylulose, which gives a positive Bial's test.

Essential pentosuria is an inborn error of metabolism in the glucoronic acid pathway, in which the step of conversion of L-xylulose to D-xylulose is catalyzed by two enzymes, xylitol dehydrogenase and xylulose reductase. The absence of any of these enzymes leads to pentosuria.

L-xylulose gives a positive Benedict's test and Bial's test.

Benedict's test is a test for identifying reducing sugars. Positive Benedict's usually indicate the presence of glucose; it may also be seen in lactosuria, galactosuria, fructosuria, and pentosuria.

Bial's test is a test for the identification of pentoses.

Other options:

Option A: As the patient's glucose tolerance test is negative and Bial’s test is negative, we rule out diabetes mellitus.

Option B: Galactosuria also gives a positive Benedict's test, since galactose is a reducing sugar, but Bial's test is negative, so we rule out galactosemia. Mucic acid test is specific for galactose.

Option D: Fructosuria also gives a positive Benedict's test since fructose is a reducing sugar, but a negative Bial's test. So we rule out fructosemia. The rapid furfural test and Selwanoff's test are specific for fructose.

questions.text: 41. Wobble hypothesis states that _________

choices.text: The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the first nucleotide of the codon triplet
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the middle nucleotide of the codon triplet
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the last nucleotide of the codon triplet
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in all the nucleotides of the codon triplet

questions.solution:
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the last nucleotide of the codon triplet. 

Wobble hypothesis essentially conveys that the base pairing which occurs between the last nucleotide and the corresponding nucleotide of the anticodon is not necessarily based on the Watson-Crick rule. It helps to explain the degeneracy of the genetic code.

For example, three codons for glycine—GGU, GGC, and GGA—can form a base pair from one anticodon, 3′ CCI 5′ ie, I, inosine, can base pair with U, C, and A. Hence I which is at the third position follows Wobble hypothesis. Similarly, U at the wobble position can pair with both A or G, as shown below:

questions.text: 42. Which of the following vitamins is the most likely to be deficient in a patient with selenium deficiency ?
questions.solution:
Patients with selenium deficiency are most likely to have concomitant vitamin E deficiency.

Selenium (Se) functions as a nonspecific intracellular antioxidant, working in conjunction with vitamin E. The presence of vitamin E helps decrease the body's need for selenium. Conversely, a deficiency in selenium leads to a reduction in tissue vitamin E levels.

Vitamin E is the most potent and naturally occurring antioxidant.

Protective antioxidant nutrients:

* Vitamin E

* Vitamin C

* Vitamin A and the carotenoids

* Selenium

* Polyphenolic compounds derived from plant foods

Current therapeutic use of vitamin E is recommended in diseases causing fat malabsorption, severe pancreatic insufficiency, and cholestatic liver disease.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile, leading to hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
43. A biochemist is studying the effect of RNA interference on gene expression. He comes across the biogenesis of miRNA. Arrange the following events involved in this process in correct chronological order.

* Transported out of nucleus via exportin 5

* Trimming by dicer

* Trimming by Drosha

* Loading into RISC complex

miRNA: Micro Ribonucleic acid RISC: RNA-induced silencing complex
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events involved in the biosynthesis of miRNA is 3,1,2,4, i.e., trimming by Drosha → transported out of nucleus via exportin 5 → trimming by dicer → loading into RISC complex. 

miRNA is an endogenous non-coding RNA. The primary function of miRNA is to modulate the translation of target mRNAs into their corresponding proteins. After the target RNA is transcribed from its gene (post-transcriptional), the miRNA may either induce mRNA cleavage or repress its translation. This is referred to as gene silencing.

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs. The miRNA belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

Mechanism of biosynthesis of miRNA:

* The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by the enzyme Drosha intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an exportin 5 protein.

* The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming by an enzyme called dicer into mature single-stranded miRNA.

* The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RISC.

* The target mRNAs contain seed sequences in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determine the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

miRNA expression is dysregulated in many cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic, referred to as oncomiRs, and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumor-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers.



Small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) are short RNA sequences that can be introduced experimentally into cells and then serve as substrates for the dicer enzyme and interact with the RISC in a manner similar to that observed for endogenous miRNAs.

Synthetic siRNAs targeted against specific mRNA species are useful in the study of gene function referred to as knockdown technology. siRNAs are also being developed as possible therapeutic agents to silence pathogenic genes, such as oncogenes involved in neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: 44. A 50-year-old man diagnosed with lung carcinoma shows elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP). The type of ALP isoenzyme elevated in this patient closely resembles which of the following isoenzymes?

questions.text: 45. Total ATP generated per turn of the TCA cycle(considering one molecule of pyruvate enters it) is
questions.solution:
10 ATP are generated per turn of the TCA cycle.

The following steps of the TCA yield ATP:

* Isocitrate to alpha-keto glutarate – Yields 1 NADH per turn

* Alpha keto glutarate to Succinyl CoA – yields 1 NADH per turn

* Succinyl CoA to Succinate – yields 1 GTP (Substrate level phosphorylation)

* Succinate to fumarate – Yields 1 FADH2

* Malate to Oxaloacetate – Yields 1 NADH

The NADH and FADH₂ molecules carry high-energy electrons to the ETC, where they are used to create a proton gradient that drives ATP synthesis. The commonly accepted ATP yields from these coenzymes are:

* 1 NADH ≈ 2.5 ATP

* 1 FADH₂ ≈ 1.5 ATP

Also, 1 GTP = 1 ATP

Using these values, the total ATP equivalents produced from the Krebs cycle per turn are:

(3 NADH × 2.5 ATP)+(1 FADH2 ​× 1.5 ATP)+ 1 ATP = 7.5 + 1.5 + 1 = 10 ATP



ATP synthesis happens in two ways:

1. Substrate level phosphorylation: Direct synthesis of ATP (or GTP) from high-energy phosphate compounds, by transfer of a phosphate group directly to ADP (or GDP). It does not require oxygen, does not involve the electron transport chain (ETC), and happens in the cytoplasm and mitochondria.

2. Oxidative Phosphorylation: Indirect ATP synthesis by transfer of electrons through the electron transport chain (ETC) in mitochondria, creating a proton gradient that drives ATP synthase. ATP is synthesized by the chemiosmotic Fo-F1 particle activity.

Pearl PM0080: Energy production in TCA Cycle

Reaction  Enzyme Method of ATP Generation Net ATP Produced
Isocitrate to alpha keto glutarate Isocitrate dehydrogenase From NADH 1*2.5 ATP per NADH = 2.5 ATP
Alpha keto glutarate to Succinyl CoA α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex From NADH 1*2.5 ATP per NADH = 2.5 ATP
Succinyl Co A to Succinate Succinate thiokinase GTP 1GTP
Succinate to fumarate Succinate dehydrogenase From FADH2 1*1.5 ATP per FADH2 = 1.5 ATP
Malate to Oxaloacetate Malate dehydrogenase From NADH 1*2.5 ATP per NADH = 2.5 ATP
    Total ATP produced per turn of the TCA 10 ATP


Pearl PM0091: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: 46. All of the following enzymes involved in heme synthesis are present in the mitochondria, except?
questions.solution:
Among the given enzymes involved in heme synthesis, ALA-dehydratase is present outside the mitochondria.

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase, protoporphyrinogen oxidase, and ferrochelatase are present inside the mitochondria. ALA-dehydratase is present in the cytosol.



The steps in heme synthesis are as follows:

Succinyl-CoA (intermediary product of the TCA cycle) combines with glycine to form α-amino-β-ketoadipic acid with the help of pyridoxal phosphate. This in turn forms α-amino-δ-levulinic acid (ALA) in the presence of ALA synthase, which occurs in the mitochondria.

Following the exit of ALA into the cytosol, the reaction catalyzed by cytosolic ALA-dehydratase condenses two molecules of ALA, forming porphobilinogen. The reactions involved in converting porphobilinogen to coproporphyrinogen III occur in the cytosol.

The last 3 reactions of heme synthesis then occur in the mitochondria. Coproporphyrinogen III enters the mitochondria and is sequentially converted to protoporphyrin-IX catalyzed by coproporphyrinogen oxidase (Option A) and protoporphyrinogen oxidase (Option B).   

Ferrous (Fe2+) iron is introduced into protoporphyrin-IX, and heme is formed in the presence of ferrochetalase (Option C).

Globin, the protein component formed by ribosome combines with heme to form hemoglobin.

questions.text: 47. Which among the following pairs is an example of epimers?
questions.solution:
Glucose and mannose are examples of epimers.

Isomers differing as a result of variations in the configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, or 4 of glucose are known as epimers. They differ only in one carbon atom. For example,

* Mannose is an epimer of glucose at carbon 2

* Galactose is an epimer of glucose at carbon 4



Compounds that have the same chemical formula but different structures are called isomers of each other. For example, fructose, glucose, mannose, and galactose all have the same chemical formula, C6H12O6, but they have different structures. The important types of isomers are:

* D and L isomers/ Enantiomers- They differ in the orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the carbon atom adjacent to the terminal alcohol carbon (carbon atom 5 in glucose). If the -OH is present on the right side, it is called the D-isomer; if the -OH group is present on the left side, it is called the L-isomer. Most of the naturally occurring sugars are D-sugars. They are mirror images of each other.



* Anomerism- This is seen in the ring structure of carbohydrates. The orientation of -H and -OH differ in the 1st carbon atom. E.g., α-glucopyranose and β-glucopyranose.



* Epimers- Isomers differing as a result of variations in the configuration of the —OH and —H on carbon atoms 2, 3, or 4 of glucose. E.g., mannose and galactose are epimers of glucose at carbon 2 and carbon 4, respectively.

* Aldose-ketose isomers- They have the same molecular formula but differ in the functional group. E.g., D-glycerose and dihydroxyacetone, D-xylose and D-xylulose, D-ribose, and D-ribulose, etc.



* Optical isomers- They differ in optical activity. When a beam of polarised light is passed through a solution of the optical isomer, it can rotate the light either to the right side or to the left side. If the light deviates to the right, it is dextrorotatory (+), and if the light deviates to the left, it is called levorotatory (-). E.g., glucose in solution is dextrorotatory, and naturally occurring fructose is levorotatory.

questions.text: 48. Which of the following blot transfer techniques is used to detect protein-DNA interaction?
questions.solution:
The South-western blot is used to detect protein-DNA interaction. 

The South-western blot or overlay blot is used to examine protein-protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions, respectively.

Process: Proteins are first separated by SDS-PAGE, transferred to a nitrocellulose/nylon membrane, and then renatured. The membrane is incubated with a labeled DNA probe, which binds specifically to DNA-binding proteins.

Detection (by autoradiography or fluorescence) reveals the protein of interest, thus combining features of Southern (DNA probe) and Western (protein separation) blots.

Other options:

Option A: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA.

Option B: Western blotting is used for the detection of proteins.

Option C: Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.

questions.text: 49. Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway?

choices.text: Ubiquitin binds to the protein by non–α-peptide bonds
Defect in this pathway leads to Angelman syndrome

questions.solution:
Ubiquitin mainly targets extracellular proteins is an incorrect statement.

The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is the pathway to degrade regulatory proteins with short half-lives and abnormal or misfolded proteins present in the cytoplasm. This pathway requires ATP. Ubiquitin is a polypeptide present in all eukaryotic cells. It mainly targets the intracellular proteins.

On identifying the target protein, it binds to it with the non–α-peptide bonds. The target protein may be bound by a single ubiquitin or multiple ubiquitin molecules. The tagged proteins are then degraded by the proteasome.



Genetic disorders that result from the defect in the ubiquitin proteasome pathway include Angelman syndrome, autosomal recessive juvenile Parkinson's disease, von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and congenital polycythemia. 

For the discovery of ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation, Aaron Ciechanover and Avram Hershko of Israel and Irwin Rose of the United States were awarded the 2004 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

questions.text:
50. A patient presented with features shown in the image. His lipid profile showed almost nil HDL levels. Which of the following is deficient in this condition?

HDL - High density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with orange tonsils and nil HDL suggests a diagnosis of Tangier's disease. It is caused by a defect in ABCA1 receptors.

ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells to HDL. Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. 

Tangier's disease is a rare, autosomal dominant condition that stems from a defect in cellular cholesterol efflux, leading to reduced HDL levels in the blood. The underlying biochemical issue is the absence of "ATP-Binding Cassette Transporter-A1" (ABCA1), which is crucial for transferring cellular cholesterol to HDL.

Plasma HDL is low, and the alpha band is not prominent during electrophoresis. Cholesterol esters accumulate in tissues, leading to manifestations such as large orange-yellow tonsils, muscle atrophy, recurrent peripheral neuropathies, and atherosclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Defective LDL receptor points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia). This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes hyperchylomicronemia (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease, which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

Pearl PM2169: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and eruptive xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and tendon xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL  Atherosclerosis, palmar and tuberoeruptive xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis
